title: European Heritage Label: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Union action for the European Heritage Label
background: The European Commission proposed transforming the intergovernmental European Heritage Label initiative, established in 2006 with 64 designated sites across member states, into a formal EU action to enhance visibility and promote cultural cohesion. The Parliament will discuss establishing common criteria and governance structures for the label to strengthen recognition of shared European heritage.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the European Heritage Label as a vital tool for strengthening European identity through cultural diversity, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to fostering shared historical consciousness.  
EPP applauds the label's focus on symbolic educational value over aesthetic criteria, effectively advancing EPP's priority of citizen engagement with Europe’s democratic roots.  
EPP proposes enhancing clarity in Article 4 to explicitly distinguish the label’s European dimension from UNESCO’s global heritage framework, ensuring unique visibility for EU integration narratives.  
EPP endorses the biennial selection cycle and expert panel structure as mechanisms to balance rigor with procedural efficiency, reflecting EPP’s emphasis on subsidiarity-compliant governance.  
EPP highlights the label’s potential to boost cultural tourism and local economies while promoting intercultural dialogue, consistent with EPP’s 2023 cultural cohesion agenda.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the European Heritage Label as a transformative tool for fostering pan-European identity, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cultural cohesion and participatory citizenship.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 5 to mandate EU-level validation panels with regional representation, ensuring selection processes reflect shared European values beyond national interests.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s recognition of linguistic diversity, echoing their 2023 manifesto priority to protect minority cultures through transnational heritage narratives.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the label’s potential to drive sustainable tourism economies, urging integration with the European Year of Cultural Heritage initiatives for amplified impact.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need for digital accessibility frameworks in Annex II to ensure labeled sites engage younger generations across all member states.

ALDE strongly advocates the European Heritage Label initiative as a strategic tool to reinforce European unity through cultural diversity, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to transnational cooperation and shared democratic values.  
ALDE applauds the issue's emphasis on psychological and financial benefits for designated sites, noting this mirrors their 2023 priorities for cultural investment as a catalyst for European identity.  
ALDE emphasizes the Label’s role in countering nationalist fragmentation by showcasing how Europe’s "mosaic of nations" strengthens rather than diminishes sovereign identities.  
ALDE proposes enhancing educational components in Article 4 to explicitly link heritage sites with civic education on EU freedoms, ensuring the Label becomes a living narrative of European integration.  
ALDE approves the budgetary pragmatism of EUR 1.3 million, urging future evaluations to quantify tourism and cohesion impacts as proof of the program’s multiplier effect.

SD strongly sanctions the establishment of the European Heritage Label as a vital tool for fostering cross-border cultural cohesion and advancing shared historical narratives, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to European integration through symbolic educational initiatives.  
SD strongly endorses the expert-led selection criteria emphasizing transnational sites and youth engagement, proposing enhanced partnerships with schools to deepen participatory heritage education programs.  
SD strongly approves the issue’s safeguards against overlap with UNESCO designations, suggesting formalized collaboration mechanisms to clarify complementary roles while preserving the label’s distinct EU identity.  
SD strongly advocates for prioritizing industrial heritage recognition as outlined in the report, aligning with SD’s focus on inclusive historical narratives that reflect Europe’s socio-economic evolution and regional diversity.  
SD strongly sanctions the six-year monitoring framework for labeled sites, urging minor adjustments to include local community feedback in renewal assessments to strengthen grassroots ownership.

ECR firmly againsts the creation of a "European Union Heritage Label" as an artificial political construct that imposes federalist identity narratives, conflicting with their principle of preserving authentic national sovereignty.  
ECR rejects the exclusion of historical sites predating EU integration, arguing this erases Europe's true diversity in favor of homogenized "Europeism" contrary to subsidiarity.  
ECR condemns allocating €1.35 million in taxpayer funds for bureaucratic duplication of UNESCO’s work, inconsistent with fiscal responsibility during cultural austerity measures.  
ECR highlights the issue’s failure to prevent politicized selection criteria, enabling exclusion of heritage reflecting Europe’s complex pre-EU historical realities.  
ECR opposes embedding EU integration agendas into heritage management, which distorts preservation goals into tools for centralized identity engineering.

GUE_NGL slightly advocates the proposal only if it removes references to constructing a "single European identity" in Article 2(c), which contradicts the historical reality of Europe's diverse class struggles and cultural conflicts.  

GUE_NGL requests revising Clause 5 to explicitly prohibit labeling sites connected to colonial exploitation or neoliberal policies that destroyed local heritage, addressing the destruction caused by CAP/CFP as noted in the debate.  

GUE_NGL opposes designating heritage "of the European Union" rather than "within the European Union," demanding amended criteria in Annex I to prevent historical revisionism favoring EU institutional narratives.  

The proposal fundamentally challenges with GUE_NGL's stance that cultural policy must reject instrumentalization for EU legitimacy-building, requiring deletion of Paragraph 14's call to "enhance faith in EU leaders."  

GUE_NGL highlights the issue's failure to address how EU austerity measures directly erode living cultural heritage, proposing binding measures in Article 7 to protect communities from economic governance-driven disintegration.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0076) concerning cultural cooperation under Article 167 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, emphasizing adherence to subsidiarity principles following a national parliament’s reasoned opinion. It endorsed the Committee on Culture and Education’s report (A7‑0311/2010), formally adopting its first-reading stance while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts. The resolution underscored the need to align the proposal with EU cultural policy objectives and instructed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity and institutional accountability.

title: Early years learning: REPORT on Early Years Learning in the European Union
background: Disparities in early childhood education access across EU member states, linked to socio-economic factors and varying national definitions of quality, alongside evidence of underinvestment compared to other education stages, prompted review. The Parliament will discuss early childhood education and care policies to address developmental impacts and equitable service provision in the EU.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the issue's emphasis on universal ECEC access as foundational for social equity and economic growth, aligning with EPP's commitment to human capital development.  
EPP approves mandatory pre-school years and staff qualification alignment with primary teachers, reflecting EPP's 2023 manifesto priorities for education quality.  
EPP endorses leveraging EU programs like Comenius for best-practice exchanges, consistent with EPP's cross-border cooperation principles in the Europe 2020 strategy.  
EPP proposes enhancing parental engagement provisions to include financial recognition for caregivers choosing home-based childcare, maintaining alignment with family autonomy values.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous implementation of multilingual curricula to advance intercultural understanding, directly supporting EPP's integration agenda for migrant communities.

EFD firmly disputes the issue’s EU-wide ECEC frameworks as a centralized overreach inconsistent with principles of national sovereignty and subsidiarity.  
EFD rejects mandatory preschool years and multilingual curricula mandates, viewing them as cultural homogenization that erodes distinctive national education systems.  
The proposal’s emphasis on universal access overlooks fiscal responsibility, conflicting with EFD’s advocacy for market-driven solutions over public spending expansions.  
EFD criticizes EU-wide monitoring standards as bureaucratic interference, arguing Member States should retain autonomy in early childhood policy design.  
While recognizing marginalized groups’ needs, EFD opposes the issue’s universal mandates as incompatible with targeted, family-centered approaches to social inclusion.

GREEN_EFA entirely supports the issue's integration of multilingual education frameworks, perfectly aligning with their decades-long advocacy for linguistic diversity as a cornerstone of European identity and social inclusion.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the universal access mandate, recognizing it as a transformative tool to address intergenerational inequalities faced by refugees and children with disabilities, in full accordance with their equity-centered policy platform.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on staff professionalization through parity with primary teachers, viewing this as essential to dismantling historical undervaluation of early-years educators—a priority in their 2024 Education Justice Manifesto.  

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the issue's economic validation of ECEC investments, affirming that its focus on long-term societal savings over short-term budgetary constraints mirrors their "Prevention Over Cure" fiscal reform principles.  

GREEN_EFA endorses the intercultural community models, seeing them as operationalizing their vision of education systems that celebrate diversity while countering nationalist fragmentation trends.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue’s emphasis on universal ECEC access, aligning with their commitment to social equity and inclusion for marginalized groups such as migrants and children with disabilities.  
ALDE approves the focus on staff qualifications and professional training, noting this is critical to achieving the cognitive and emotional development goals outlined in the report.  
ALDE highlights the economic rationale for ECEC investment, strongly endorsing its long-term benefits in workforce participation and reduced social costs, consistent with ALDE’s growth-oriented policies.  
ALDE endorses multilingual curricula and intercultural activities, proposing enhanced partnerships with local cultural institutions to deepen community integration.  
ALDE suggests expanding vocational training linkages within ECEC frameworks to better align early skill development with future labor market demands, ensuring seamless transitions for youth.

SD strongly agrees the issue's universal ECEC access mandate, aligning perfectly with their commitment to educational equity for marginalized groups and socioeconomic inclusion.  
SD applauds the economic prioritization of early childhood investment, noting Maria Badia i Cutchet's emphasis on its unmatched developmental returns and long-term societal cost reductions.  
SD proposes adopting binding EU-wide quality criteria for ECEC services to address Vilija Blinkevičiūtė's identified data gaps, ensuring standardized monitoring of outcomes for disabled and disadvantaged children.  
SD endorses multilingual curricula and staff qualification parity with primary teachers as critical for achieving Olga Sehnalová's cited integration and EU 2020 education targets.  
SD urges enhanced parental engagement mechanisms through amended labor policies, reflecting the issue's holistic approach to early learning ecosystems.

ECR rejects the issue's EU-mandated childcare targets as a direct infringement on Member States' competence over education under subsidiarity principles.  
ECR opposes standardized staff qualification requirements, arguing they impose uniform EU frameworks incompatible with diverse national education systems.  
ECR completely rejects with the issue's emphasis on expanded public ECEC funding, prioritizing fiscal restraint and opposing EU budgetary overreach.  
ECR condemns universal access mandates for neglecting practical barriers to implementation, including local labor market flexibility needs.  
ECR criticizes multilingual curriculum provisions for enabling coercive language policies that undermine minority rights, as seen in Lithuania's disputed reforms.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical importance of high-quality early childhood education and care (ECEC) as foundational for lifelong learning, social equity, and achieving Europe 2020 targets, emphasizing its role in cognitive, emotional, and physical development. It highlighted the need to revise the 2002 Barcelona targets (90% childcare coverage for children aged 3+ and 33% for under-3s) to prioritize children’s best interests, urging universal access regardless of socioeconomic background, including marginalized groups like migrants, refugees, and children with disabilities. The resolution stressed ECEC’s economic benefits, including reduced future health and social costs, increased workforce participation, and lower crime rates, advocating for increased investment despite economic challenges. It called for mandatory pre-school years, multilingual and inclusive curricula, staff qualifications aligned with primary teachers, improved staff-to-child ratios, and continuous professional training. The Parliament emphasized parental engagement through flexible labor policies, parental leave, and advisory services, while promoting intercultural activities and community-integrated ECEC models. It urged Member States to address disparities in ECEC access, monitor quality standards, and foster EU-wide research and best-practice exchanges, particularly under initiatives like Comenius, to enhance evidence-based policies and cross-border cooperation.

title: Erasmus for all programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing "ERASMUS FOR ALL" The Union Programme for Education, Training, Youth and Sport
background: Persistently high youth unemployment across EU member states and identified skills mismatches in labor markets, alongside existing EU education mobility programs (Erasmus, Comenius, Leonardo da Vinci), prompted evaluation of program effectiveness under Europe 2020 strategy targets. The Parliament will discuss consolidating educational initiatives into a unified framework addressing transnational learning opportunities and workforce development.

stances.stance:
EPP totally advocates the consolidated Erasmus+ structure as perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to efficient EU governance through streamlined program management and reduced administrative costs.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the budget prioritization for higher education mobility programs that directly combat youth unemployment through enhanced employability skills.  
EPP fully supports the issue's integration of sport funding as a strategic tool for social inclusion and anti-discrimination efforts across member states.  
EPP endorses the doubling of cross-border educational mobility targets by 2020 as effectively advancing EPP's vision of European identity formation through grassroots cultural exchange.  
EPP fully approves the expanded Eastern Partnership provisions that strengthen educational ties with Moldova and Ukraine, reinforcing EPP's neighborhood policy priorities.

EFD supports the increased budget allocation for education-work linkages but advises stricter monitoring mechanisms to prevent leisure misuse of funds.  
EFD proposes amending sports inclusion criteria to address discrimination against European artistic gymnastics schools in international tournaments.  
EFD raises concerns about the program’s alignment with EU political objectives, advocating decentralized management to preserve national sovereignty.  
EFD questions the proportionality of the €17.2 billion budget, urging cost-benefit analysis amid youth economic challenges.  
EFD emphasizes rigorous oversight of mobility programs to ensure skill development over symbolic EU identity-building.

GREEN_EFA completely advocates the issue's tripling of youth initiative funding as a transformative investment in intergenerational solidarity and social cohesion.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the prioritization of vocational education's 17% allocation, recognizing its multiplier effects on sustainable growth and labor market responsiveness.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the rigorous monitoring framework for student loan guarantees, ensuring it advances debt-conscious mobility without compromising borrower protections.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the 7% operational budget for Mediterranean academic cooperation must be augmented through synergies with EU Neighborhood Policy instruments.  
GREEN_EFA affirms that the issue's employability focus inherently addresses youth unemployment through Article 9's complementarity clause with the European Social Fund.

SD firmly sanctions the creation of a dedicated youth chapter with autonomous budgeting, perfectly aligning with SD's longstanding commitment to amplifying non-formal education and cross-border solidarity among young Europeans.  
SD perfectly aligns with the preservation of iconic program identities like Erasmus and Leonardo da Vinci, recognizing their critical role in maintaining institutional recognition and accessibility for beneficiaries across generations.  
SD firmly sanctions the issue’s emphasis on quadrupling mobility opportunities for disadvantaged socioeconomic groups, effectively advancing SD's priority of educational equity as a cornerstone of social inclusion.  
SD perfectly aligns with the integration of sport as a distinct funding pillar, reinforcing SD's principle that grassroots athletic initiatives are essential for fostering European identity and community cohesion.  
SD firmly sanctions the rejection of loan-based mobility schemes as primary instruments, upholding SD's manifesto commitment to grant-based support systems that prevent debt barriers to transnational learning.

ECR strongly advocates the enhanced focus on vocational training and youth mobility, which aligns with their commitment to fostering employability and cross-cultural understanding.  
ECR approves the dedicated budget for grassroots sport initiatives, recognizing their vital role in community development and social cohesion.  
ECR proposes reallocating a portion of Jean Monnet funding toward expanding sport and adult learning opportunities to maximize tangible societal benefits.  
ECR endorses the subsidiarity-driven administrative framework, ensuring member states retain flexibility in program management per local needs.  
ECR applauds the program’s emphasis on equitable access to education, advancing their priority of empowering individuals across all demographics.

GUE_NGL absolutely disapproves the inclusion of student loan guarantees in the Erasmus for All programme, as this promotes debt-based education access contrary to their commitment to free public higher education for all.  
GUE_NGL rejects the proposal's alignment with neoliberal policies, arguing that substituting grants with loans exacerbates inequality and mirrors exclusionary systems like the United States'.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as the need for state-funded scholarships to ensure underprivileged youth can pursue studies without financial barriers.  
This issue conflicts with GUE_NGL's principle that education must remain a public good, not commodified through market-driven mechanisms.  
GUE_NGL condemns the programme's failure to mandate member states to expand grant systems, thereby institutionalizing educational inequity across the EU.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a proposed education and training program, allocating budget shares as follows: 25% to higher education, 17% to vocational education and training and adult learning, 7% to school education, and 7% to youth initiatives. The resolution emphasized enhancing skills, employability, and mobility across member states, aligning the program with EU priorities such as sustainable growth, innovation, and social inclusion. It stressed the need for efficient use of funds, rigorous monitoring, and collaboration with stakeholders to address labor market needs and demographic challenges. The Parliament called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original proposal, ensuring transparency and coherence with broader EU objectives.

title: Creative Europe programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on establishing the Creative Europe Programme
background: The EU’s separate MEDIA, Cultura, and MEDIA Mundus programs supported cultural and audiovisual sectors facing market fragmentation, digital transition, and global competition. Cultural/creative industries contributed 5-7% of EU GDP and employment. Under the 2014-2020 MFF and Treaty of Lisbon provisions, the Parliament will discuss establishing the Creative Europe Programme to integrate these sectors, promoting diversity and competitiveness.

stances.stance:
EPP fully agrees the Creative Europe programme as perfectly aligning with its commitment to cultural diversity and economic competitiveness through creative industries.  
EPP emphasizes the programme's critical role in preserving European values and identity while proposing enhanced vigilance on the guarantee fund's adaptation to cultural operators' needs.  
EPP applauds the integration of MEDIA programmes and cross-border cultural exchanges as exemplary tools to strengthen Europe’s global cultural leadership.  
EPP highlights the urgency of increased budgetary ambition to match the cultural sector’s proven crisis-resilience and job-creation potential.  
EPP underscores the necessity of prioritizing digital innovation and heritage protection to amplify Europe’s unique creative profile globally.

GREEN_EFA totally accepts the issue's emphasis on cultural exchange and artist mobility as essential to fulfilling the EU's Treaty obligations.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the integration of the UNESCO Convention on cultural diversity, affirming that art must transcend mere commercial value.  
GREEN_EFA celebrates the prioritization of small-scale projects and non-profits as a critical victory against purely economic program orientations.  
GREEN_EFA acknowledges the budget limitations as an enhancement opportunity to further amplify cultural diplomacy in future MFF negotiations.  
GREEN_EFA recognizes the issue’s alignment with their manifesto by safeguarding creative sector jobs and intercultural dialogue mechanisms.

ALDE strongly sanctions the Creative Europe programme's integration of cultural and media initiatives, aligning perfectly with ALDE's commitment to fostering innovation-driven economic growth through streamlined EU action.  
ALDE applauds the financial instrument enabling private sector engagement, effectively advancing their priority of leveraging market mechanisms to amplify cultural sector sustainability.  
ALDE proposes enhancing digitization provisions by accelerating copyright framework reforms to better facilitate cross-border access to creative content, while maintaining full support for the programme’s core structure.  
ALDE approves the issue’s recognition of cultural industries’ economic significance, mirroring their longstanding advocacy for valuing creativity beyond GDP metrics in EU policymaking.  
ALDE highlights the programme’s alignment with Treaty of Lisbon obligations for cultural diversity as critical to preserving Europe’s competitive edge in global creative markets.

SD absolutely accepts the Creative Europe programme's unification of cultural and media initiatives under a single framework while preserving sector-specific autonomy, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to integrated European cultural policies.  

SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on sufficient funding, proposing enhanced budgetary allocations to maximize the programme's capacity to support micro-enterprises and digital transformation in cultural sectors.  

SD absolutely accepts the prioritization of cultural diversity and linguistic preservation as cornerstones of European identity, particularly through structured support for audiovisual industries and cross-border creative collaborations.  

SD emphasizes the programme's proven role in generating 4.5% of EU GDP and 3.5% annual employment growth in cultural sectors, urging intensified focus on vocational training pathways to amplify these economic benefits.

ECR strongly approves the prioritization of small and medium enterprises in the Creative Europe programme, aligning with their commitment to market-driven economic growth and innovation.  
ECR applauds the issue's emphasis on geographical balance, effectively advancing equitable access to cultural funding for Central and Eastern European member states.  
ECR endorses the inclusion of European Neighborhood Policy countries, reinforcing their strategic goal of fostering stability through cultural cooperation with eastern partners.  
ECR proposes enhancing administrative mechanisms to ensure streamlined SME participation without increasing bureaucratic burdens.  
ECR recognizes the programme’s value in promoting European identity while maintaining respect for national cultural sovereignty.

GUE_NGL supports the unified structure of Creative Europe but advises explicit safeguards against treating culture as a commodity, referencing UNESCO conventions on cultural diversity.  
GUE_NGL calls for amendments to Article 4 requiring member states to report on artists’ labor conditions and social security coverage in funded projects.  
GUE_NGL emphasizes resisting austerity-driven cuts to cultural budgets, urging Parliament to allocate at least 1% of the MFF to grassroots cultural initiatives.  
GUE_NGL proposes revising eligibility criteria to prioritize cooperatives and non-profit entities over commercial operators in media funding streams.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need for crisis-response mechanisms to protect cultural workers from precarity, aligning with Treaty obligations on social cohesion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the financial framework for EU programs from 2014 to 2020, emphasizing that the proposed budget in the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0785) remains indicative pending final agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). It reiterated its 2011 resolution advocating for a 5% increase in the MFF compared to 2013 levels to meet EU priorities, including Treaty of Lisbon obligations, competitiveness, sustainability, and solidarity, while warning that even this increase would inadequately address agreed objectives. The resolution challenged the Council to justify potential cuts to EU priorities if opposing such funding, stressing the need to preserve initiatives with proven European added value. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantially amended and underscored the urgency of aligning resources with the EU’s political and legal commitments to avoid undermining shared goals.

title: Cross-border voluntary activities in the EU: REPORT on recognising and promoting cross-border voluntary activities in the EU
background: The European Year of Volunteering 2011 highlighted the role of 100 million EU volunteers contributing 5% of GDP, alongside challenges in cross-border coordination and legal barriers. The Parliament will discuss enhancing recognition and support for transnational voluntary activities to strengthen social cohesion and civic engagement.

stances.stance:
EPP totally promotes the issue’s emphasis on cross-border volunteering as a cornerstone of social cohesion and intercultural solidarity, perfectly aligning with EPP’s commitment to fostering active citizenship and intergenerational dialogue.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call for integrating volunteer-acquired skills into the European Skills Passport, enhancing youth employability and lifelong learning in line with EPP’s economic growth priorities.  
EPP totally promotes the creation of a European Volunteer Centre Development Fund, recognizing its potential to amplify cross-border collaboration while safeguarding against labor market displacement.  
EPP proposes strengthening administrative simplification measures to eliminate bureaucratic barriers for volunteers, ensuring seamless mobility across Member States without compromising legal safeguards against labor exploitation.  
EPP perfectly aligns with leveraging exemplary initiatives like the Charlemagne Youth Prize to scale best practices, reinforcing volunteering’s role in bridging regional disparities as highlighted in the issue.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on preventing volunteering from replacing paid labor or absolving state responsibilities, aligning perfectly with their commitment to social justice and dignified work conditions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing the legal framework provisions by mandating explicit reference to the European Charter on the Rights and Responsibilities of Volunteers in all Member State implementations.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the integration of volunteering into social inclusion strategies, particularly for marginalized groups, as this effectively advances their priority of equitable participation in civic life.  
GREEN_EFA endorses strict differentiation between voluntary altruism and profit-driven activities, urging stricter safeguards in corporate social responsibility clauses to prevent exploitation.  
GREEN_EFA strongly promotes cross-border volunteering expansion through EU funding mechanisms, recognizing its potential to strengthen transnational solidarity networks central to their Green New Deal vision.

ALDE fundamentally promotes the issue’s recognition of volunteer time as match funding for EU projects, perfectly aligning with their commitment to empowering civil society through innovative financial mechanisms.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for VAT exemptions for non-profits, viewing this as essential to reduce administrative burdens and enhance the fiscal sustainability of cross-border volunteering initiatives.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on resisting austerity-driven cuts to voluntary sector support, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for robust public-private partnerships in social cohesion efforts.  
ALDE fundamentally promotes the integration of volunteering into EU strategic frameworks like Europe 2020, recognizing this as a critical step to mainstream active citizenship in policy design.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s push for the European Skills Passport, underscoring their priority of validating non-formal learning to strengthen labor market inclusion.

SD entirely agrees the call for strengthened legal frameworks on volunteer protections and non-discrimination, perfectly aligning with their commitment to social justice and inclusive participation across all EU member states.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on cross-border volunteering as a catalyst for intercultural exchange, advocating for expanded mobility programs that leverage retirees’ expertise through initiatives like the proposed humanitarian corps.  
SD entirely agrees integrating volunteer-gained skills into the European Skills Passport, recognizing this mechanism as vital for bridging non-formal education with labor market opportunities in line with SD’s lifelong learning priorities.  
SD perfectly aligns with the demand to embed volunteering across EU policy architectures, particularly noting its synergistic potential with cohesion funds to advance social solidarity and active citizenship continent-wide.  
SD entirely agrees the issue’s insistence on safeguarding volunteerism from labor substitution, upholding their principled stance that civic participation must complement rather than undermine worker protections and public service obligations.

ECR firmly opposes the issue's funding expansion for cross-border programs as conflicting with fiscal responsibility principles.  
ECR rejects mandatory EU-level volunteer frameworks that risk undermining national sovereignty in social policy domains.  
The proposal overlooks critical cost-control mechanisms for insurance and tax coordination under Regulation 2004/883, creating unsustainable burdens.  
ECR opposes using volunteer time as matching EU funding, viewing this as indirect labor market interference.  
The issue's VAT exemptions for non-profits contradict ECR's stance against selective market distortions.

GUE_NGL supports the issue’s emphasis on empowering marginalized groups and preventing volunteering from replacing paid labor, aligning with their commitment to workers’ rights and social justice.  
GUE_NGL advises amending the issue to explicitly call for a **European Statute for Associations**, ensuring legal clarity and financial stability for volunteer organizations operating cross-border.  
GUE_NGL recommends revising funding provisions to distinguish **grants for NGOs** from state aid frameworks, safeguarding associations from arbitrary budget cuts during austerity periods.  
GUE_NGL highlights the need to integrate VAT exemptions for non-profits more robustly, linking this to the issue’s tax framework improvements to reduce administrative burdens.  
GUE_NGL stresses caution regarding corporate social responsibility initiatives, urging stricter safeguards to prevent privatization of volunteer efforts while supporting cross-border best practice sharing.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the multifaceted benefits of volunteering, emphasizing its role in fostering social cohesion, active citizenship, intercultural learning, and solidarity across generations, while contributing to sustainable development, poverty reduction, environmental protection, and economic growth through GDP contributions. It highlighted volunteering’s capacity to enhance social inclusion, empower marginalized groups, and aid integration, particularly for people with disabilities and older adults transitioning to retirement. The resolution stressed that volunteering must not replace paid labor or absolve governments of social obligations, especially in the care sector, nor become a mandatory requirement. It urged the Commission and Member States to expand inclusive cross-border volunteering opportunities, improve legal frameworks for insurance, tax, and social security (notably under Regulation 2004/883), and allocate adequate funding, including a European Volunteer Centre Development Fund. The Parliament called for recognition of skills gained through volunteering via the European Skills Passport, integration of volunteering into EU policies (e.g., Europe 2020, Millennium Development Goals), and promotion during the 2013 European Year of Citizens. It advocated VAT exemptions for non-profit organizations, adoption of the ILO Manual for data collection, and use of volunteer time as matching funding for EU projects, while encouraging corporate social responsibility initiatives and cross-border networks to share best practices.

title: Cultural dimensions of EU external actions: REPORT on the cultural dimensions of the EU’s external actions
background: The EU's existing cultural cooperation frameworks, including the 2005 UNESCO Convention, Treaty on European Union provisions, and initiatives like the European Agenda for Culture, established commitments to integrate cultural considerations in external relations. The Parliament will discuss strategies to systematically incorporate cultural dimensions into EU foreign policy and development actions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the integration of cultural diplomacy across EU external actions, particularly endorsing the creation of a dedicated Directorate-General for Cultural and Digital Diplomacy to advance Europe’s global influence through structured cultural exchange.  
EPP applauds the emphasis on expanding Erasmus and Youth in Action programs, aligning with their manifesto commitment to fostering European identity through educational mobility and cross-border collaboration.  
EPP proposes enhancing VAT harmonization for digital cultural goods to ensure fair competition with non-EU platforms, addressing disparities while maintaining strong intellectual property protections as outlined in the issue.  
EPP fundamentally agrees leveraging cultural industries as economic drivers, emphasizing their role in job creation and social cohesion, and urges accelerated implementation of the Danube Strategy to unlock regional creative potential.  
EPP highlights the need to prioritize broadband investment and Europeana’s expansion to combat digital divides, ensuring cultural access aligns with their digital single market priorities.

EFD rejects the issue's push for centralized EU cultural diplomacy as fully disapproveing with its principle of preserving national sovereignty and distinct cultural identities.  
EFD opposes the creation of a Directorate-General for Cultural and Digital Diplomacy, viewing it as bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with subsidiarity and a threat to Europe's "glorious tapestry" of independent cultures.  
EFD condemns the proposal for cultural visas and expanded EU educational programs, arguing it accelerates brain drain from struggling member states like Lithuania while promoting wasteful spending on "meaningless" pan-European initiatives.  
EFD fundamentally disputes the issue's technological focus through platforms like Europeana, asserting it fails to address core concerns about cultural homogenization and the erosion of local heritage preservation methods.  
EFD challenges the €1 million EU-UNESCO agreement as emblematic of misplaced priorities, insisting funds should instead bolster national cultural institutions rather than "grey amorphous" EU projects.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue's integration of cultural diplomacy across EU external policies, aligning perfectly with their commitment to fostering inclusive societies through mobility and intercultural exchange.  
GREEN_EFA approves the emphasis on cultural visas and streamlined mobility for artists, proposing enhanced coordination with Member States to standardize accelerated visa procedures for third-country cultural professionals.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the prioritization of digital cultural platforms like Europeana, which directly advances their manifesto goals for democratizing access to Europe’s diverse heritage while safeguarding net neutrality.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the linkage between cultural rights and conflict prevention, urging explicit inclusion of artist protection clauses in EEAS training programs for personnel operating in conflict zones.  
GREEN_EFA highlights an enhancement opportunity to strengthen contractual fairness for digital content creators, suggesting a review of cross-border intellectual property frameworks to complement the issue’s economic growth objectives.

SD strongly endorses the integration of cultural diplomacy across EU external actions, aligning perfectly with SD's commitment to fostering inclusive societies through initiatives like cultural visas and expanded access to EU educational programs.  
SD applauds the issue's emphasis on combating illicit cultural trafficking and protecting heritage, which effectively advances SD's human rights priorities by integrating cultural rights into broader frameworks.  
SD proposes enhancing coordination mechanisms by accelerating the establishment of the Directorate-General for Cultural and Digital Diplomacy, addressing concerns about fragmented initiatives raised during debates.  
SD strongly endorses leveraging digital platforms like Europeana for cultural dissemination, reinforcing SD's longstanding advocacy for net neutrality and equitable digital access.  
SD welcomes the €1 million EU-UNESCO agreement as a model for cultural governance but suggests explicit inclusion of grassroots artists in funding allocations to strengthen local ownership.

ECR slightly accepts the issue's emphasis on cultural diplomacy but requests revisions to Article 12 establishing a Directorate-General for Cultural Diplomacy, which conflicts with subsidiarity principles by centralizing authority best held by Member States.  
ECR totally doubts Paragraph 29's mandate for cultural coordinators in EU delegations, viewing this as bureaucratic overreach inconsistent with ECR's commitment to minimizing EU institutional bloat.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of budget discipline by advocating new training programs (Paragraph 41) without offsetting cuts, contradicting ECR's austerity priorities in external action spending.  
ECR rejects the issue's silence on enforcing minority language protections in Member States like Lithuania, where Paragraph 15's principles on inclusive education are systematically violated.  
While supporting youth mobility initiatives (Paragraphs 7-9), ECR demands strict limits on EU involvement in curricula to prevent encroachment on national education sovereignty.

GUE_NGL partially sanctions the issue's cultural diplomacy framework but demands explicit rejection of market-driven approaches to cultural goods in trade agreements, citing Marie-Christine Vergiat's opposition to commodification.  
GUE_NGL requests revisions to Article 12 to prohibit private-sector funding mandates for cultural institutions, aligning with João Ferreira's critique of austerity-driven underfunding in education and heritage preservation.  
GUE_NGL fundamentally doubts the issue's implicit endorsement of the Bologna Process education reforms, echoing Paul Murphy's condemnation of their corporate alignment and fee-based exclusion.  
GUE_NGL requires amendment of Clause 7 to exclude cultural/educational programs from IMF/ECB austerity conditionalities, reflecting Ferreira's warning about the "obscurantist intervention plan" undermining public access.  
GUE_NGL insists on deleting references to "creative industries" in Clause 3 unless redefined to prohibit intellectual property commercialization, per Vergiat's rejection of market-subjected cultural policies.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of culture in advancing EU external relations, emphasizing its cross-cutting importance in fostering tolerance, inclusive societies, economic growth, and mutual understanding. It stressed integrating cultural considerations into all EU external policies, trade agreements, and development programs, including the European Neighbourhood Policy, Eastern Partnership, and Union for the Mediterranean, while leveraging instruments like the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights (EIDHR). The resolution highlighted the need to streamline fragmented cultural initiatives, enhance coordination across EU institutions, and establish a dedicated Directorate-General for Cultural and Digital Diplomacy within the European External Action Service (EEAS), alongside appointing cultural coordinators in EU delegations. It advocated for cultural visas to ease mobility for artists, expanded access to EU cultural and educational programs for third-country nationals, and the creation of a central EU portal to promote cultural events and networking. The Parliament condemned internet censorship, reaffirmed net neutrality, and urged investment in broadband to bolster digital access and platforms like Europeana for cultural dissemination. It welcomed a €1 million EU-UNESCO agreement to support cultural governance in developing countries and called for protecting cultural heritage, combating illicit trafficking, and integrating cultural rights into human rights frameworks. The resolution further urged prioritizing cultural diplomacy in conflict prevention, peace-building, and democratization, including training for personnel in conflict zones, and demanded a 2011 Green Paper to formalize a cohesive EU strategy on culture in external relations, ensuring alignment with the UNESCO Convention and the dual nature of cultural goods in trade negotiations.

title: Implementation of the EU youth strategy 2010-2012: REPORT on implementation of the EU Youth Strategy 2010-2012
background: The EU faced rising youth unemployment, increased NEET populations, and economic losses from youth labor market disengagement between 2010-2012, alongside austerity-driven cuts to education and youth programs. The Parliament will discuss the implementation and outcomes of the EU Youth Strategy 2010-2012 in addressing these socioeconomic challenges.

stances.stance:

EPP advocates reversing unjustified cuts to education budgets, particularly the €3 million reduction for European Schools, as a critical enhancement opportunity to maintain quality training aligned with ICT and green economy sectors.  
EPP strongly endorses leveraging Horizon 2020 and Erasmus for All to address brain drain, stressing the need for credible financing mechanisms to uphold youth mobility and skills development as outlined in the issue.  
EPP proposes systemic budget reforms to eliminate payment inefficiencies, ensuring sustainable funding for digital inclusion and entrepreneurship programs central to reducing NEET rates.

EFD requests revisions to structural reform clauses to prohibit new EU-level spending commitments inconsistent with national austerity realities.

GREEN_EFA entirely accepts the issue's demand for increased EU funding to youth programs, perfectly aligning with their insistence on closing budget gaps to prevent austerity-driven underinvestment in education and climate priorities.

ECR opposes expanding Youth Guarantee Scheme funding without binding amendments to Section 5(c) prohibiting new debt instruments for youth initiatives.  
ECR requests revision of Paragraph 23 to prioritize budget discipline over "raising MFF allocations," citing current €153 billion economic losses from mismanaged programs.  
ECR supports entrepreneurship promotion measures only if amended to include strict auditing clauses mirroring Court of Auditors' road project waste recommendations.  
ECR fundamentally rejects the issue's approach to Horizon 2020 expansions, stating it conflicts with their manifesto commitment to "zero-growth EU budgets" during austerity periods.

GUE_NGL supports the issue's condemnation of austerity cuts to youth programs but advises reversing MFF budget reductions through amendments specifying minimum 7% annual increases in education allocations.  
GUE_NGL endorses expanding the Youth Guarantee Scheme while proposing structural reforms to accelerate EU Structural Fund disbursements, preventing payment delays documented in 2013-2014 budgets.  
GUE_NGL highlights concerns that current vocational training provisions risk perpetuating gender disparities unless amended to mandate equal ICT/green economy access for young women.  
GUE_NGL advises strengthening welfare protections in mobility programs by incorporating Erasmus for All housing subsidies for low-income participants.  
GUE_NGL stresses the need to combat brain drain through binding clauses requiring Member States to implement living wage guarantees in national youth action plans.

resolution: The European Parliament raised urgent concerns over the severe youth unemployment crisis, noting a 23.5% EU-wide rate in 2013, with 7.5 million young people aged 15–24 and 6.5 million aged 25–29 classified as NEETs (not in education, employment, or training), resulting in an estimated economic loss of €153 billion (1.2% of EU GDP) in 2011. It criticized austerity-driven cuts to education and training programs, which exacerbated inequalities, brain drain, and precarious employment, while stressing the need for structural reforms and increased funding, including raising the proposed €6 billion MFF allocation for youth initiatives. The resolution emphasized enhancing cross-sectoral cooperation under the EU Youth Strategy (2010–2018), prioritizing quality apprenticeships, vocational training aligned with labor market needs (e.g., ICT, healthcare, green economy), and expanding the Youth Guarantee Scheme to under-30s, supported by EU Structural Funds. It advocated for improved youth participation via structured dialogue, recognition of non-formal learning, and digital inclusion through initiatives like open educational resources and social media engagement. Additional measures included promoting entrepreneurship via microfinance, addressing gender disparities in employment, reducing early school-leaving rates, and leveraging programs like Erasmus for All, Horizon 2020, and the European Year of Citizens to foster mobility, skills development, and civic engagement. The Parliament urged Member States to implement national action plans, ensure welfare protection for mobile workers, and prioritize youth autonomy, social inclusion, and anti-discrimination efforts to prevent a "lost generation."

 Debate remarks about supporting distance learning for women and disabled individuals conflict with score; opposition stems from rejection of EU institutional overreach in education.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of enhancing lifelong learning, digital education, and gender equality to address societal and economic challenges. It emphasized the need to integrate academic further and distance education into EU strategies, particularly to adapt to technological changes and labor market demands, noting that by 2025, 49% of EU job openings will require high-level qualifications. The resolution highlighted the role of digital tools in improving accessibility, flexibility, and inclusivity, especially for women, who face underrepresentation in STEM fields (only 3% of female graduates hold ICT degrees) and could boost EU GDP by €9 billion annually if gender parity in ICT is achieved. It called for bridging the digital divide, investing in infrastructure, and ensuring quality assurance in distance education, while urging Member States to support teacher training, ICT literacy, and validation of non-formal learning. The Parliament stressed the importance of Erasmus+, Horizon 2020, and vocational training to enhance mobility and skills, alongside revising the European Qualifications Framework to improve recognition of qualifications. It advocated for targeted measures to combat gender stereotypes, promote women’s participation in education and employment, and address barriers for disadvantaged groups, including refugees and low-skilled adults, through flexible learning pathways and affordable, personalized education options.

title: Erasmus': the Union programme for education, training, youth and sport: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing ‘Erasmus’: the Union programme for education, training, youth and sport and repealing Regulation (EU) No 1288/2013
background: The Erasmus Union program, operational since 1987, supported education, training, youth, and sport mobility across Europe, with over 9 million participants by 2018. The European Commission proposed a 2021-2027 regulation to renew and expand its scope. The Parliament will discuss adopting the proposed regulation, addressing program structure, funding levels, and accessibility measures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and adopted its position at first reading on the Commission’s 2018 proposal (COM(2018)0367) to strengthen education, vocational training, and lifelong learning, aligning with Treaty provisions on education and vocational training (Articles 165(4) and 166(4)). The resolution called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments are made, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It highlighted the role of the Committee on Culture and Education’s report, supported by opinions from the Committees on Development, Budgets, and Employment and Social Affairs, in shaping priorities such as reducing skills gaps, enhancing mobility programs, and addressing youth unemployment. The resolution also noted input from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, stressing cross-sectoral collaboration to align policies with labor market needs and EU cohesion objectives.

The resolution emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if it substantially alters or replaces its original proposal, ensuring parliamentary oversight. It further directed its President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence while advancing policy objectives in cultural and economic domains.

title: Implementation of the Bologna process: REPORT on Follow-up on the implementation of the Bologna Process

By 2015, 47 EHEA signatories faced persistent challenges including youth unemployment, skills mismatches, and uneven implementation of agreed reforms. The Parliament will discuss progress and obstacles in advancing the Process’s goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities regarding the Bologna Process and the European Higher Education Area (EHEA), emphasizing the need to address persistent challenges such as youth unemployment (5 million under-25s unemployed in the EU in 2014) and skills mismatches affecting labor markets. It highlighted achievements over 15 years, including enhanced comparability of higher education systems, mobility frameworks, and quality assurance mechanisms, while stressing the urgency of aligning education with labor market needs, improving employability, and fostering innovation through STEM disciplines. The resolution called for increased investment in education and research, urging adherence to the EU target of 3% GDP allocated to R&D by 2020, and warned against cuts to Horizon 2020 and Erasmus+ funding, which are vital for research, mobility, and the 2020 target of 20% student mobility. It advocated for stronger quality assurance through European Standards and Guidelines (ESG), mutual recognition of qualifications, and integration of National Qualifications Frameworks with the EHEA. The Parliament emphasized social inclusion, equitable access to education, and support for disadvantaged groups, including refugees, while promoting digitalization, interdisciplinary studies, and partnerships between universities, businesses, and governments. It underscored the need for a student-centered approach, lifelong learning (LLL), and the Europe 2020 goal of 40% tertiary education attainment among 30-34-year-olds. The resolution also called for enhanced data collection, global cooperation to boost the EHEA’s competitiveness, and a critical review of progress at the 2015 Yerevan Ministerial Conference to reinvigorate the Bologna Process.

It stressed the economic significance of cultural sectors, contributing 4.4% of EU GDP and 3.8% of employment, and called for future programme iterations (2021-2028) to prioritize artistic quality, operational grants for networks, and a potential European observatory on culture. Key demands included expanding the Financial Guarantee Facility to boost SME access, balancing economic and artistic criteria in funding decisions, and ensuring equitable geographic distribution of resources to sustain Europe’s global cultural competitiveness.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns about the underfunding and implementation challenges of the Europe for Citizens (EfC) Programme 2014-2020, which aims to promote European remembrance, democratic engagement, and civic participation through two strands: "European Remembrance" (fostering awareness of shared history and values) and "Democratic Engagement and Civic Participation" (encouraging citizen involvement in EU policymaking). Despite its symbolic importance, the programme’s budget of €185.47 million (0.0171% of the Multiannual Financial Framework) was deemed insufficient, with a 13.7% cut leading to a 25% reduction in funded projects by 2014 and a mere 6% success rate for remembrance and civil society projects in 2015, compared to higher rates in other programmes like Creative Europe. The Parliament highlighted the programme’s impact, including 1.1 million participants in 408 projects in 2015, but stressed that limited funding caused frustration among applicants and hindered goals. It called for a budget increase to €500 million (€1 per citizen) in the next MFF, simplified procedures, enhanced synergies with programmes like Erasmus+ and Creative Europe, and improved communication through a centralized online platform. Recommendations included prioritizing town-twinning initiatives, addressing contemporary challenges (migration, radicalization, social inclusion), ensuring accessibility for marginalized groups, and formalizing multiannual priorities. The resolution also urged legal reforms to grant Parliament co-legislative authority over the programme, criticized the lump-sum funding system for disadvantaging smaller organizations and regions with higher costs, and emphasized the need for transparent feedback on rejected applications. Additionally, it advocated for greater international participation, including EFTA and candidate countries, and leveraging social media to amplify outreach and promote EU values amid rising Euroscepticism.

title: European Solidarity Corps programme: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the European Solidarity Corps programme and repealing [European Solidarity Corps Regulation] and Regulation (EU) No 375/2014
background: The European Solidarity Corps, initiated in 2016, aimed to foster youth engagement in volunteering and solidarity activities. Existing EU programmes, including the EU Aid Volunteers, operated separately, prompting calls for consolidation. The Parliament will discuss establishing a revised ESC programme to harmonise implementation, enhance accessibility, and address societal needs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to enhance the European Solidarity Corps (ESC) by streamlining processes and expanding outreach, aiming for over 350,000 placements over seven years through improved communication strategies, including social media campaigns, ESC ambassadors, and targeted outreach in remote areas. The resolution emphasized inclusivity by proposing part-time opportunities for disadvantaged youth, limiting in-country activities to projects with strong inclusion objectives, and mandating feedback on inclusion outcomes. It stressed aligning ESC activities with societal needs, particularly social inclusion and humanitarian challenges, and integrating a robust learning component in jobs and traineeships, restricted to non-profit tasks. The Parliament advocated adopting work programmes through delegated acts to ensure co-legislator oversight, defining "solidarity" and "volunteering" to unify program implementation, and fostering long-term civic engagement. Participants are to receive advance learning outcome details and meaningful feedback to maximize personal growth, while stakeholders, including youth networks, should be regularly consulted to strengthen program relevance and impact.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and outlined priorities for enhancing education and training systems under the ET2020 framework, emphasizing inclusive, high-quality education as a fundamental right and public good essential for social cohesion, economic growth, and democratic values. It stressed the need to address persistent challenges such as educational poverty, socio-economic disparities, low adult learning participation, early school leaving (targeting a reduction below 10%), and insufficient digital and basic skills. The resolution advocated for improved teacher training, better working conditions, and higher salaries to attract and retain qualified educators, while promoting innovative pedagogies and ICT integration, including digital competencies and open educational resources. It highlighted the urgency of integrating migrants, refugees, and asylum seekers through language support, recognition of qualifications, and inclusive curricula, alongside measures to counter radicalization and foster intercultural dialogue. The Parliament called for balanced investment in STEM and humanities disciplines, cautioning against overemphasis on labor-market outcomes at the expense of critical thinking, creativity, and ethical values. It endorsed the Europe 2020 target of 40% tertiary education attainment but urged quality assurance, dual education models, and validation of non-formal learning. Additional priorities included addressing brain drain, enhancing mobility programs like Erasmus+, and mainstreaming gender equality to close gaps in access and outcomes. The resolution urged Member States to leverage EU funding tools, improve policy coordination, and share best practices to achieve these goals while respecting national competencies and regional diversity.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical need to address global food security, nutrition, and sustainable agriculture through the Milan Expo 2015 theme "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life," emphasizing the paradox of 870 million undernourished people alongside 2.8 million deaths linked to obesity and poor diets. It highlighted the EU’s agricultural sector as vital, contributing €1 trillion annually and employing over 4 million people, while stressing the urgency of reducing food waste—projected to rise to 126 million tonnes in the EU by 2020 without intervention. The resolution called for binding targets to combat food waste, sustainable intensification of agriculture, and support for small-scale and family farming, particularly in developing countries where 70% of the workforce depends on agriculture. It urged leveraging Expo 2015 to promote the right to healthy, informed food choices, address land degradation and "land grabbing," and integrate climate action into food policies, including through the Paris 2015 Climate Agreement. The Parliament emphasized reversing the decline in development aid for agriculture, empowering women in farming, and aligning trade and investment policies with food security goals. It advocated for education on nutrition, reducing food waste, and promoting agroecological practices, while endorsing the "Milan Charter" as a legacy document to advance Sustainable Development Goals, aiming to end malnutrition by 2030 and ensure equitable access to resources, innovation, and fair supply chains.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the imperative to establish a European Education Area (EEA) by 2025, emphasizing quality, inclusive, and accessible lifelong learning to address disparities exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, including unequal access to digital infrastructure affecting socioeconomically disadvantaged groups. It stresses the need to reduce early school leavers to 5% and under-skilled 15-year-olds in core subjects below 10%, while increasing adult learning participation to 50%. The Parliament called for allocating at least 10% of national recovery budgets and increasing public education spending above the EU average of 4.7% of GDP (2019), alongside targeted investments in teacher training, digital infrastructure, and vocational education to address gaps in AI programs and promote dual education systems. The resolution highlights inclusion for vulnerable groups, climate education aligned with the European Green Deal, gender equality in STEAM fields, and combating disinformation through media literacy. It urges governance frameworks like the EEA Strategic Framework 2030 with multi-level collaboration, a European dimension in curricula covering EU history and citizenship, and partnerships with UNESCO and OECD. Key sectoral measures include fostering plurilingualism, recognizing non-formal learning, developing micro-credentials with EU-wide standards, and ensuring face-to-face learning remains central, supplemented by blended approaches. The Parliament also emphasized disaster preparedness for education systems and the role of European Universities and Centres of Vocational Excellence in driving excellence and mobility.
